Introduction

We are all part of a single species, with a common origin that dates back hundreds of thousands of years (History Tracers, ). Despite this fundamental equality, countless cases of mistreatment of our fellow human beings have occurred throughout history, including slavery in different periods (Centre d'Estudis, Debats i Tertúlies), as we will see below.

The Babylonian Captivity

Determining the beginning of the Babylonian captivity is a complex task (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, ; Horn, S. H, , pp. 13 - 15). According to the Babylonian chronicles, we know that:

• Nebuchadnezzar left for Palestine (Hatti-land) in Kislev of his 7th regnal year (= to ), and that he seized "the city of Judah" (= Jerusalem) on Adar 2 (= ). Moreover, it is stated that on that day he "captured the king" and "appointed there a king of his own choice." This provides an exact date for the end of Jehoiachin's reign and the accession of Zedekiah (Horn, S. H, , pp. 20 - 21).

Based on the Babylonian chronicles and Jewish scriptures, we may conclude that the fall of Jerusalem occurred in , with the deportation of the Jews taking place within this time frame (Horn, S. Mathematics in History

Mathematical limits (History Tracers, , Natural limits) help us estimate when certain events occurred.

In the previous section, time intervals were presented that indicate a starting point (minimum) and an endpoint (maximum), which delimit the probable period in which an event took place.

In everyday life, many people prefer to deal with exact values. However, since this is not always possible, it is necessary to work with approximations, establishing limits that define the most likely time frame in which events occurred.

Slavery in the Iberian Peninsula

The practice of slavery and persecutions in the Iberian Peninsula are ancient, as documented by the Centre d'Estudis, Debats i Tertúlies (Centre d'Estudis, Debats i Tertúlies). In various Councils of Toledo, there are records of Jewish slaves and Church slaves (Montero, Pedro, ; CEDT, ESPAÑA VISIGODA: Los Concilios de Toledo sobre los esclavos de la Iglesia; y sobre la esclavitud y los judíos).
Centuries later, with the beginning of Portuguese maritime expeditions, the papal bull "ROMANUS PONTIFEX" on , granted Portugal the right to enslave the peoples of conquered lands:

• Nos, premissa omnia et singula debita meditatione pensantes, ac attendentes quod cum olim prefato Alfonso Regi quoscunque Sarracenos et paganos aliosque Christi inimicos ubicunque con­ stitutos, ac regna, ducatus, principatus, dominia, possessiones, et mobilia ac immobilia bona quecunque per eos detenta ac possessa invadendi, conquirendi, expugnandi, debellandi, et subjugandi, illorumque personas in perpetuam servitutem redigendi, ac regna, ducatus, comitatus, principatus, dominia, possessiones, et bona sibi et successoribus suis applicandi, appropriandi, ac in suos successorumque suorum usus et utilitatem convertendi, aliis nostris litteris

[translation: We, considering all and each detail with due attention, and recognizing that, with the said King Afonso, all Muslims, pagans, and other enemies of Christ, wherever they may be, as well as their kingdoms, duchies, principalities, dominions, possessions, and movable and immovable goods, might be invaded, conquered, subdued, and their persons reduced to perpetual servitude, transferring their goods for the use and benefit of the king, his successors, and heirs].

The bull was not the only document that laid the foundation for persecutions in the Portuguese kingdom. Eduardo Bueno presents other examples on his channel (Bueno, Eduardo, ).

Beyond the Bull

Slavery was also mentioned by Arab writers. Ibn Khaldūn described the Black people of Lamlam being invaded and enslaved:

  • "... Negro people called Lamlam. They are unbelievers. They brand themselves on the face and temples. The people of Ghâmah and Takûr invade their country, capture them, and sell them to merchants who transport them to the Maghrib. There, they consitute the ordinary mass of slaves..." (Rosenthal, Franz, , pp. 118 - 119).

Indigenous Slavery

When Europeans arrived in the Americas, Indigenous peoples were initially viewed as labor to be enslaved. This becomes evident when analyzing various inventories (Arquivo Público do Estado de São Paulo).

Was There Slavery in India?

Although slavery was practiced in many parts of the world, its presence in India is debatable. The way of life of the Shudras, for example, might not necessarily be considered slavery (Karim Khan, Abdul, ; Patil, S., , pp. 33). S. Patil, in his work, also highlights the diversity of opinions contrary to the idea that India did not experience slavery (Patil, S., , pp. 37 - 41, 46 - 47).

When addressing cultural and historical issues, it is essential to proceed with caution so as not to impose our own standards, thereby avoiding misinterpretations or offensive conclusions. Applying our criteria to unfamiliar practices may lead to misunderstandings.
